ratings.comment: Professor Paul is exactly what you would want out of a philosophy teacher. Even when the content is dry, she keeps students involved by posing good questions to the class and leaving lots of room for discussion. She represents all of the philosophical viewpoints covered in class fairly, and she allows you to draw your own conclusions.
I loved having Professor Paul as a teacher. She is extremely intelligent and encourages questions and discussion in lecture. She is a well-published philosopher and I loved talking to her.

I liked her; intelligent and interesting person. One thing I didn't like was when she said things like "this seems correct" to certain philosophies, even though she said she wasn't there to convince us to believe in a certain philosophy. Overall, very interesting and fun class with an above average professor.  Didn't read, went to lecture, did well

Philosophy of mind is interesting, this class was not, primarily because she allowed discussion of inane topics to go on for far too long. She didn't grade our papers, even though it was an upper level class-- and we had no interaction with the person who was. She seems neat on a one-on-one basis, but just not so as a lecturer.

Her lectures were essentially her regurgitating exactly what was in the assigned reading  on a powerpoint with zero clarification. She shut down class discussions and would only briefly entertain questions. Seemed like she had no clue what she was talking about and I didn't really learn much in lecture. I was constantly so bored.

Class was completely unnecessary, for she ran the 40-person course like an open discussion.  The readings were fairly dense, and I hoped for some clarification, but I never found it.  Showing up to class was completely useless, besides the fact that she grades based on attendance.  Would highly suggest taking another professor.
Excellent professor; the course is difficult, but Professor Paul is more than willing to help you work through the concepts. She knows her stuff. If you have the chance to take P-Paul, then take it.

Good: patient, young, female,  homework and tests are of medium difficulty, lecture slides online, organized thoughts  Improvable: her 101 is not as substantive as other professors' (hers is more interactive, maybe excessively so)

She assigns about 10 pages of reading for each lecture, but she goes over all the parts you will be tested on in her PowerPoints, so it's not really necessary to read them. The tests were pretty fair, but there was definitely a time crunch (about 50 minutes for 5+ short answers and one long essay). Prof. Paul's lectures were conversational and fun.

Professor Paul is great! This is an interesting and very fair class. The only homework is reading, and you don't even have to do that because she goes over everything you need to know for the test. She pretty much tells you what the test will be like, and she gives you the essay question. There is a participation grade, so talk in discussion.

Sarah doesn't do much of the grading. There is a 15% participation grade, so talk in discussion! Also, it's fun to argue with the TAs, they're cool! Midterms and finals are all short answer and essay format. She gives you the essay question beforehand. Pretty easy class and exams. Oh! She takes attendance in lecture, so show up... but great class!
Professor Paul is a really good instructor, and she makes each class into more like a 300-person discussion than getting talked at for a dry seventy minutes.

Professor Paul is a nice professor and certainly knowledgable more than most Professors I've had in any field. However, she is stuck up, her lectures are not very clear and the readings are essential to understanding. Personally, I learned very little in lecture, but was able to do well in the class from attending the discussions. It's a good class

Philosophy 101 was definitely the worst class I have taken so far! It was not what I thought it would be about. Professor Paul is nice and is really into philosophy, unfortunately she is the only one. 3 tests and one paper. Class wasn't worth it, fell asleep most of the time. She posts the slides online. Probably could get away with not showing up.

This woman is something else.  She admits on day one this class won't get you anywhere because Philosophy has no future except becoming a professor like her.  This is a lot of conceptual thinking about life that is completely unnecessary.  I only took this to fulfill a humanities credit but would highly recommend doing any other class for that.
One of the best course I have ever taken. Very clear. I can't understand at all why someone believe she is boring. Maybe they should come to Chinese university and then rate all the professor zero.

Arrogant, boring and unenjoyable as a teacher. She expects 101 students to all have the drive and knowledge of full time philosophy majors, making the class overly difficult. She also comes off as very arrogant and holier-than-thou. Take Philosophy 101 with a different professor, I've heard great things about many of the other ones.

I did not enjoy this class at all. It was way above the level of what a 101 class should be. Professor Paul went way too in depth in the material and expected too much of the students. Her lectures were boring and to be honest, Professor Paul seemed a little full of herself. I do not recommend this class.

Definitely not a breeze. Most of the time I felt that my grades reflected her opinion of my thoughts rather than my arguments. I as if my beliefs were in question rather than my understanding of topics. I would not recommend this class to others for the sake that I just panicked about this class more than necessary for an intro class.

Professor Paul is a great teacher. I am also part of the FIG mentioned below, and I think Paul does a great job of explaining the material. She disagreed with my opinion on the paper I wrote, but I got an A nonetheless, since my argument was good. To do well in the class you should do the readings, listen in lecture, and engage in the discussions.

She is an excellent professor, and is accepting of others opinions. She grades very fairly and is extremely helpful when you don't understand something. I am also part of the FIG mentioned below, and her teaching did not make me hate this class. She is an exceptional professor, and this class should be taken by those interested in philosophy.

She is a rude, condescending and horrible professor. She expects you to follow her opinions nd ONLY her opinions. If you try and argue against her point, she will hate you for the rest of the semester. She is one of the worse professors I have come across and she made me and my entire FIG hate philosophy.

Professor Paul was an outstanding professor. Her classes were well organized and well structured, and she always drew the material from the readings. The readings weren't always easy, but she helped clarify. She was also very approachable during office hours, and I would sometimes chat with her at Memorial Union! Overall, great 101 experience.

Professor Paul is an awesome professor. I took her class as a Mechanical Engineer and really enjoyed it. It's pretty easy even without doing any of the readings as long as you're able to construct reasonably intelligent ideas.

This class was awful. Prof Paul is unbelievably full of herself and is totally worthless as a prof. She makes up words, doesn't use actual words correctly, rambles on and contradicts herself constantly. The TAs just want to hear their own opinions regurgitated back to them. Leave your real opinions at the door and tell them what they want to hear.

Action Theory Spring 2011. Younger than my other phil profs, but a nice change of pace. Well structured: Most days she had a handout with an outline.  Every other week we had to do 1.5 p. summaries/questions about a reading, which I liked b/c it forced you to do the work and do it well. Papers. no exams. Choice of final paper topic. 3500 words.
Really interesting class.  Tests are super easy and not too much work outside class.

Professor Paul is a great professor for Intro to Philosophy. Speaks clearly, and helps you with information if you don't understand it. Easy to get a B in the class, but difficult to get an A. Readings and attendance is not mandatory, but help with your grade. More of a "application" class rather than a memorization class. Highly recommended.

Prof Paul was great. Her class was really interesting and I like that she encourages discussion within lecture. There is one paper worth 35% of your grade, but you get a rough draft, if you fix the rough draft it's fine. The grades are TA based, but the one TA she had was really helpful and fair. I got an A in the class and didn't do the readings.
She is okay. The readings are hard. Need huge amount of time, if you want an A. I think for some concepts she doesn't understand at all.
liked to ramble a lot. too many readings that were hardly referred to. entire grade was based on TA. too nitpicky and base grade on final papers on how rough draft was done. ridiculous.
The class isn't too hard.  You really don't have to do any of the readings. and she gives out all of the material that you will be tested upon.

I took philosophy of mind with her. She's okay, I guess. She tends to be really talkative and uses fancy words all the time to sound smart. Most of the papers you don't really have to read - a lot of the arguments are ridiculous anyways. It's funny when she discusses psychology research because it's obvious she knows little about it.
